====Siberia and the Russian Far East==== [[Siberia]] is typically classified as a polar region, owing to the dryness of the winter climate and has glaciers only in the high [[Altai Mountains]], [[Verkhoyansk Range]], [[Cherskiy Range]] and [[Suntar-Khayata Range]], plus possibly a few very small glaciers in the ranges near [[Lake Baikal]], which have never been monitored and may have completely disappeared since 1989.<ref name=surazakov>{{cite journal|last1=Surazakov|first1=A.B.|last2=Aizem|first2=V.B.|last3=Aizem|first3=E.M.|last4=Nikitin|first4=S.A.|title=Glacier Changes in the Siberian Altai Mountains, Ob river basin, (1952–2006) estimated with high resolution imagery|journal=Environmental Research Letters|volume=2|issue=4|doi=10.1088/1748-9326/2/4/045017|url=http://iopscience.iop.org/1748-9326/2/4/045017/fulltext/|accessdate=July 6, 2015|format=PDF|pages=045017|bibcode = 2007ERL.....2d5017S |year=2007}}</ref><ref name=dyurgerov>{{cite web|last1=Dyurgerov|first1=Mark B.|last2=Meier|first2=Mark F.|title=Glaciers and the Changing Earth System: A 2004 Snapshot|url=http://instaar.colorado.edu/other/download/OP58_dyurgerov_meier.pdf|publisher=University of Colorado|accessdate=July 6, 2015|format=PDF|date=2005}}</ref><ref name=ananicheva>{{cite journal|last1=Ananicheva|first1=M.D.|last2=Krenke|first2=A.N.|last3=Barry|first3=R.G.|title=The Northeast Asia mountain glaciers in the near future by AOGCM scenarios|journal=The Cryosphere|date=October 6, 2010|volume=4|issue=4|pages=435–445|doi=10.5194/tc-4-435-2010|url=http://www.the-cryosphere.net/4/435/2010/tc-4-435-2010.pdf|accessdate=July 21, 2015|format=PDF|bibcode = 2010TCry....4..435A }}</ref> Between the years 1952 and 2006, the glaciers found in the Aktru Basin region shrank by 7.2 percent.<ref name=surazakov/> This shrinkage has been primarily in the ablation zone of the glaciers, with recession of several hundred meters being observed for some glaciers. The Altai region has also experienced an overall temperature increase of 1.2 degrees Celsius in the last 120 years according to a report from 2006, with most of that increase occurring since the late 20th century.<ref name=surazakov/>
In the more maritime and generally wetter [[Russian Far East]], [[Kamchatka]], exposed during winter to moisture from the [[Aleutian Low]], has much more extensive glaciation totaling around {{convert|906|km2|abbr=on}} with 448 known glaciers as of 2010.<ref name=ananicheva/><ref name=jones>{{cite journal|last1=Jones|first1=Vivienne|last2=Solomina|first2=Olga|title=The geography of Kamchatka|journal=Global and Planetary Change|date=June 6, 2015|issue=132|doi=10.1016/j.gloplacha.2015.06.003|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0921818115001137|accessdate=July 21, 2015|volume=134|pages=3–9|bibcode = 2015GPC...134....3J }}</ref> Despite generally heavy winter snowfall and cool summer temperatures, the high summer rainfall of the more southerly [[Kuril Islands]] and [[Sakhalin]] in historic times melt rates have been too high for a positive mass balance even on the highest peaks. In the [[Chukotskiy Peninsula]] small alpine glaciers are numerous, but the extent of glaciation, though larger than further west, is much smaller than in Kamchatka, totalling around {{convert|300|km2|mi2}}.<ref name=dyurgerov/>
Details on the retreat of Siberian and Russian Far East glaciers less adequate than in most other glaciated areas of the world. There are several reasons for this, the principal one being that since the collapse of [[Communism]] there has been a large reduction in the number of monitoring stations.<ref name=unep>{{cite web|title=Global Glacier Changes: facts and figures Northern Asia|url=http://www.grid.unep.ch/glaciers/pdfs/6_7.pdf|publisher=United Nations Environment Programme|accessdate=July 17, 2015|format=PDF}}</ref> Another factor is that in the Verkhoyansk and Cherskiy Ranges it was thought glaciers were absent before they were discovered during the 1940s, whilst in ultra-remote Kamchatka and Chukotka, although the existence of glaciers was known earlier, monitoring of their size dates back no earlier than the end of World War II.<ref name=ananicheva/> Nonetheless, available records do indicate a general retreat of all glaciers in the Altai Mountains with the exception of volcanic glaciers in Kamchatka. [[Sakha Republic|Sakha’s]] glaciers, totaling seventy square kilometers, have shrunk by around 28 percent since 1945 reaching several percent annually in some places, whilst in the Altai and Chukotkan mountains and non-volcanic areas of Kamchatka, the shrinkage is considerably larger.<ref name=unep/>
====Himalayas and Central Asia==== [[File:Glacial lakes, Bhutan.jpg|thumb|390px|This [[NASA]] image shows the formation of numerous glacial lakes at the termini of receding glaciers in [[Bhutan]]-[[Himalaya]].]] The Himalayas and other mountain chains of central Asia support large glaciated regions. An estimated 15,000 glaciers can be found in the greater Himalayas, with double that number in the Hindu Kush and Karakoram and Tien Shan ranges, and comprise the largest glaciated region outside the poles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Himalayas Facts|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/nature/the-himalayas-himalayas-facts/6341/|publisher=Nature|accessdate=August 26, 2015|date=February 11, 2011}}</ref> These glaciers provide critical water supplies to arid countries such as [[Mongolia]], western China, [[Pakistan]], [[Afghanistan]] and [[India]]. As with glaciers worldwide, those of the greater Himalayan region are experiencing a decline in mass, and researchers claim that between the early 1970s and early 2000s, there had been a 9 percent reduction in ice mass.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Laghari|first1=Javaid|title=Climate change: Melting glaciers bring energy uncertainty|journal=Nature|volume=502|issue=7473|pages=617–618|url=http://www.nature.com/news/climate-change-melting-glaciers-bring-energy-uncertainty-1.14031#/b5|accessdate=November 15, 2015|date=November 11, 2013|doi=10.1038/502617a}}</ref> Change in temperature has led to melting and the formation and expansion of glacial lakes which could cause an increase in the number of glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs). If the present trends persist the ice mass will gradually be reduced, and will affect the availability of water resources, though water loss is not expected to cause problems for many decades.<ref>{{cite web|title=Narrowing the Knowledge Gap on Glaciers in High Mountain Asia|url=http://www.icimod.org/?q=17276|website=International Symposium on Glaciology in High Mountain Asia|publisher=International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development|accessdate=August 26, 2015|date=March 9, 2015}}</ref>
In the Wakhan Corridor of Afghanistan 28 of 30 glaciers examined retreated significantly between 1976–2003, with an average retreat of {{convert|11|m|abbr=on}} per year.<ref name=haritashya>{{cite journal|last2=Bishop|last3=Shroder|last4= Bush|last5=Bulley|title=Space-based assessment of glacier fluctuations in the Wakhan Pamir, Afghanistan|year=2009|volume=94|issue=1–2|journal=Climate Change|pages=5–18|url=http://www.glims.org/glacierdata/data/lit_ref_files/haritashya2009.pdf|doi=10.1007/s10584-009-9555-9|format=PDF|last1=Haritashya|first1=Umesh K.|first2=Michael P.|first3=John F.|first4=Andrew B. G.|first5=Henry N. N.}}</ref> One of these glaciers, the [[Zemestan Glacier]], retreated {{convert|460|m|ft|abbr=on}} during this period, not quite 10% of its {{convert|5.2|km|mi|abbr=on}} length.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pelto|first1=Mauri|title=Zemestan Glacier, Afghanistan Retreats|url=http://blogs.agu.org/fromaglaciersperspective/2009/12/23/zemestan-glacier-afghanistan-retreats/|publisher=American Geophysical UNion|accessdate=November 15, 2015|date=December 23, 2009}}</ref> In examining 612 glaciers in China between 1950 and 1970, 53% of the glaciers studied were retreating. After 1990, 95% of these glaciers were measured to be retreating, indicating that retreat of these glaciers was becoming more widespread.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Sandeep Chamling Rai |author2=Trishna Gurung |author3=et alia |title=An Overview of Glaciers, Glacier Retreat and Subsequent Impacts in Nepal, India and China|format=PDF|work=WWF Nepal Program|url=http://assets.panda.org/downloads/himalayaglaciersreport2005.pdf|accessdate=November 15, 2015}}</ref> Glaciers in the [[Mount Everest]] region of the Himalayas are all in a state of retreat. The [[Rongbuk Glacier]], draining the north side of Mount Everest into [[Tibet]], has been retreating {{convert|20|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year. In the Khumbu region of Nepal along the front of the main Himalaya of 15 glaciers examined from 1976–2007 all retreated significantly and the average retreat was {{convert|28|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year.<ref name=bajracharya>{{cite web|author=Bajracharya, Mool|title=Glaciers, glacial lakes and glacial lake outburst floods in the Mount Everest region, Nepal|work=International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development|url=http://www.icimod.org/dvds/201104_GLOF/reports/final_report.pdf|format=pdf|accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref> The most famous of these, the Khumbu Glacier, retreated at a rate of {{convert|18|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year from 1976–2007.<ref name=bajracharya/> In India, the [[Gangotri Glacier]] retreated {{convert|1147|m|ft|abbr=on}} between the years 1936 and 1996 with {{convert|850|m|ft|abbr=on}} of that retreat occurring in the last 25 years of the 20th century.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Naithani|first1=Ajay K.|last2=Nainwal|first2=H. C.|last3=Sati|first3=K. K.|last4=Prasad|first4=C.|title=Geomorphological evidences of retreat of the Gangotri Glacier and its characteristics|journal=Current Science|year=2001|volume=80|issue=1|pages=87–94|url=http://www.iisc.ernet.in/currsci/jan102001/87.pdf|accessdate=November 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name=gangotri>{{cite web|title=Retreat of the Gangotri Glacier|url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=4594|publisher=NASA Earth Observatory|accessdate=November 15, 2015|date=June 23, 2004}}</ref> However, the glacier is still over {{convert|30|km|mi|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=gangotri/> In [[Sikkim]], 26 glaciers examined between the years 1976 and 2005 were retreating at an average rate of {{convert|13.02|m|abbr=on}} per year.<ref name=raina>{{cite web|last1=Raina|first1=V. K.|title=Himalayan Glaciers A State-of-Art Review of Glacial Studies, Glacial Retreat and Climate Change|url=http://www.moef.nic.in/downloads/public-information/MoEF%20Discussion%20Paper%20_him.pdf|publisher=Ministry of Environment and Forests|accessdate=November 15, 2015|format=PDF|date=2010}}</ref> Overall, glaciers in the Greater Himalayan region that have been studied are retreating an average of between {{convert|18|and|20|m|abbr=on}} annually.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Anthwal|first1=Ashish|last2=Joshi|first2=Varun|last3=Sharma|first3=Archana|last4=Anthwal|first4=Smriti|title=Retreat of Himalayan Glaciers – Indicator of Climate Change|journal=Nature and Science|date=2006|volume=4|issue=4|pages=53–59|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237397392|accessdate=November 16, 2015}}</ref> The only region in the Greater Himalaya that has seen glacial advances is in the [[Karakoram Range]] and only in the highest elevation glaciers, but this has been attributed possibly increased precipitation as well as to the correlating glacial surges, where the glacier tongue advances due to pressure build up from snow and ice accumulation further up the glacier. Between the years 1997 and 2001, {{convert|68|km|abbr=on}} long [[Biafo Glacier]] thickened {{convert|10|to|25|m|abbr=on}} mid-glacier, however it did not advance.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hewitt|first1=Kenneth|title=The Karakoram Anomaly? Glacier Expansion and the 'Elevation Effect,' Karakoram Himalaya|journal=Mountain Research and Development|date=2006|volume=25|issue=4|pages=332–340|doi=10.1659/0276-4741(2005)025[0332:tkagea]2.0.co;2}}</ref>
With the retreat of glaciers in the Himalayas, a number of glacial lakes have been created. A growing concern is the potential for [[GLOF]]s researchers estimate 21 glacial lakes in [[Nepal]] and 24 in [[Glaciers of Bhutan|Bhutan]] pose hazards to human populations should their terminal moraines fail.<ref>{{cite web|title=Glacial Lakes and Glacial Lake Outburst Floods in Nepal|url=http://www.icimod.org/dvds/201104_GLOF/reports/final_report.pdf|publisher=International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development|accessdate=November 22, 2015|page=31|format=pdf|year=2011}}</ref> One glacial lake identified as potentially hazardous is Bhutan's [[Raphstreng Tsho]], which measured {{convert|1.6|km|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.96|km|abbr=on}} wide and {{convert|80|m|abbr=on}} deep in 1986. By 1995 the lake had swollen to a length of {{convert|1.94|km|abbr=on}}, {{convert|1.13|km|abbr=on}} in width and a depth of {{convert|107|m|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Qader Mirza|first1=M. Monirul|title=Climate Change and Water Resources in South Asia|date=July 13, 2005|publisher=Taylor & Francis Ltd|isbn=978-0203020777|page=143|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qpi_S6Q6FnUC&pg=PA142&lpg=PA142&dq=Raphstreng+Tsho+expanding+Ageta#v=onepage&q=Raphstreng%20Tsho%20expanding%20Ageta&f=false|accessdate=November 22, 2015}}</ref> In 1994 a GLOF from Luggye Tsho, a glacial lake adjacent to Raphstreng Tsho, killed 23 people downstream.<ref>{{cite web|author=United Nations Environment Programme|title=Global Warming Triggers Glacial Lakes Flood Threat – April 16, 2002|work=UNEP News Release 2002/20|url=http://www.unep.org/Documents.Multilingual/Default.asp?DocumentID=245&ArticleID=3042&l=en|accessdate=November 22, 2015}}</ref>
Glaciers in the [[Ak-shirak Range]] in [[Kyrgyzstan]] experienced a slight loss between 1943 and 1977 and an accelerated loss of 20% of their remaining mass between 1977 and 2001.<ref>{{cite journal | author=T. E. Khromova, M. B. Dyurgerov and R. G. Barry| title=Late-twentieth century changes in glacier extent in the Ak-shirak Range, Central Asia, determined from historical data and ASTER imagery (Abstract)| journal=American Geophysical Union| year=2003| volume=30| issue=16| page=1863| url=http://www.agu.org/pubs/crossref/2003/2003GL017233.shtml| doi=10.1029/2003gl017233| bibcode=2003GeoRL..30.1863K}}</ref> In the [[Tien Shan]] mountains, which Kyrgyzstan shares with China and [[Kazakhstan]], studies in the northern areas of that mountain range show that the glaciers that help supply water to this arid region, lost nearly {{convert|2|km3|mi3|abbr=on}} of ice per year between 1955 and 2000. The [[University of Oxford]] study also reported that an average of 1.28% of the volume of these glaciers had been lost per year between 1974 and 1990.<ref>{{cite news|first=Alex|last=Kirby|title=Kazakhstan's glaciers 'melting fast'|date=September 4, 2003|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/3077422.stm}}</ref>
The [[Pamirs]] mountain range located primarily in [[Tajikistan]], has approximately eight thousand glaciers, many of which are in a general state of retreat.<ref name=kayumov>{{cite web|last=Kayumov|first=A.|title=Glaciers Resources of Tajikistan in Condition of the Climate Change|publisher=State Agency for Hydrometeorology of Committee for Environmental Protection under the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan|url=https://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/OSY/Meetings/GCW-IM1/glaciers.pdf|format=pdf|accessdate=January 31, 2016}}</ref> During the 20th century, the glaciers of Tajikistan lost {{convert|20|km3|mi3|abbr=on}} of ice.<ref name=kayumov/> The {{convert|70|km|mi|abbr=on}} long [[Fedchenko Glacier]], which is the largest in Tajikistan and the largest non-polar glacier on Earth, retreated {{convert|1|km|mi|abbr=on}} between the years 1933 and 2006, and lost {{convert|44|sqkm|abbr=on}} of its surface area due to shrinkage between the years 1966 and 2000.<ref name=kayumov/> Tajikistan and neighboring countries of the Pamir Range are highly dependent upon glacial runoff to ensure river flow during droughts and the dry seasons experienced every year. The continued demise of glacier ice will result in a short-term increase, followed by a long-term decrease in glacial melt water flowing into rivers and streams.<ref>{{cite web|last=Novikov|first=V.|title=Tajikistan 2002, State of the Environment Report|work=Climate Change|publisher=Research Laboratory for Nature Protection (Tajikistan)|url=http://enrin.grida.no/htmls/tadjik/soe2001/eng/htmls/climate/state.htm|accessdate=January 31, 2016}}</ref>
===Northern hemisphere — North America=== [[File:Lewist.jpg|thumb|The Lewis Glacier, [[North Cascades National Park]] after melting away in 1990]] North American glaciers are primarily located along the spine of the Rocky Mountains in the United States and Canada, and the Pacific Coast Ranges extending from northern [[California]] to [[Alaska]]. While [[Greenland]] is geologically associated with North America, it is also a part of the Arctic region. Apart from the few tidewater glaciers such as [[Taku Glacier]], in the advance stage of their [[tidewater glacier cycle]] prevalent along the coast of Alaska, virtually all of those in North America are in a state of retreat. This rate has increased rapidly since around 1980, and overall each decade since has seen greater rates of retreat than the preceding one. There are also small remnant glaciers scattered throughout the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] mountains of California and [[Nevada]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Huegel|first=Tony|title=Sierra Nevada Byways: 51 of the Sierra Nevada's Best Backcountry Drives (Backcountry Byways)|year=2008|publisher=Wilderness Press|isbn=978-0-89997-473-6|pages=2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=lqF-mz0HMkYC&pg=PA2&dq=remnant+glaciers+in+california#v=onepage&q=remnant%20glaciers%20in%20california&f=false|accessdate=2011-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Castor|first=Stephen B.|title=Proceedings of the 39th Forum on the Geology of Industrial Minerals, Nevada|year=2004|publisher=Nevada Bureau of Mines and Geology|pages=192|url=https://books.google.com/?id=zxZpWTnRXpEC&pg=PA192&dq=glaciers+in+the+state+of+nevada#v=onepage&q=glaciers%20in%20the%20state%20of%20nevada&f=false|author2=Keith G, Papke, Richard O. Meeuwig|accessdate=2011-10-15}}</ref>
====Cascade Range==== The [[Cascade Range]] of western North America extends from southern [[British Columbia]] in Canada to northern California. Excepting Alaska, about half of the glacial area in the U.S. is contained within the over 700 glaciers of the [[North Cascades National Park|North Cascades]], a portion of those located between the Canada–US border and [[I-90]] in central [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]. These contain much water as is found in all the lakes and reservoirs in the rest of the state, and provide much of the stream and river flow in the dry summer months, approximating some {{convert|870000|m3|yd3|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pelto|first=Mauri S.|title=Recent Global Glacier Retreat Overview|url=http://www.nichols.edu/departments/glacier/glacier_retreat.htm|accessdate=2011-10-15}}</ref> [[File:Bouldert.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[Boulder Glacier (Washington)|Boulder Glacier]] retreated {{convert|450|m|ft|abbr=on}} from 1987 to 2003.]] [[File:Eastonterm.jpg|thumb|250px|The Easton Glacier retreated {{convert|255|m|ft|abbr=on}} from 1990 to 2005.]] As recently as 1975 many North Cascade glaciers were advancing due to cooler weather and increased precipitation that occurred from 1944 to 1976. By 1987 the North Cascade glaciers were retreating and the pace had increased each decade since the mid-1970s. Between 1984 and 2005 the North Cascade glaciers lost an average of more than {{convert|12.5|m}} in thickness and 20–40 percent of their volume.<ref name=pelto2/>
Glaciologists researching the North Cascades found that all 47 monitored glaciers are receding while four glaciers—[[Spider Glacier (Phelps Ridge, Washington)|Spider Glacier]], [[Lewis Glacier (Oregon)|Lewis Glacier]], [[Milk Lake Glacier]] and [[David Glacier]]—have disappeared completely since 1985. The [[White Chuck Glacier]] (near [[Glacier Peak]]) is a particularly dramatic example. The glacier area shrank from {{convert|3.1|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} in 1958 to {{convert|0.9|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} by 2002. Between 1850 and 1950, the [[Boulder Glacier (Washington)|Boulder Glacier]] on the southeast flank of [[Mount Baker]] retreated {{convert|8700|ft}}. William Long of the United States Forest Service observed the glacier beginning to advance due to cooler/wetter weather in 1953. This was followed by a {{convert|743|m}} advance by 1979.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Mauri S. Pelto |author2=Cliff Hedlund | title= Terminus behavior and response time of North Cascade glaciers, Washington, U.S.A | journal= Journal of Glaciology| year= 2001| volume= 47| issue= 158| pages= 497–506| url= http://www.nichols.edu/departments/glacier/terminus_behavior_and_response_t.htm| doi= 10.3189/172756501781832098|bibcode = 2001JGlac..47..497P }}</ref> The glacier again retreated {{convert|450|m|ft|abbr=on}} from 1987 to 2005, leaving barren terrain behind. This retreat has occurred during a period of reduced winter snowfall and higher summer temperatures. In this region of the Cascades, winter [[snowpack]] has declined 25% since 1946, and summer temperatures have risen 0.7 [[Celsius|°C]] (1.2 [[Fahrenheit|°F]]) during the same period. The reduced snowpack has occurred despite a small increase in winter precipitation—thus, it reflects warmer winter temperatures leading to rainfall and melting on glaciers even during the winter. As of 2005, 67% of the North Cascade glaciers observed are in disequilibrium and will not survive the continuation of the present climate. These glaciers will eventually disappear unless temperatures fall and frozen precipitation increases. The remaining glaciers are expected to stabilize, unless the climate continues to warm, but will be much reduced in size.<ref>{{cite web | author=Mauri S. Pelto |publisher=[[Nichols College]] | title=North Cascade Glacier Terminus Behavior | url=http://www.nichols.edu/departments/glacier/north%20cascade%20glacier%20retreat.htm | accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref>
====U.S. Rocky Mountains==== On the sheltered slopes of the highest peaks of [[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park]] in [[Montana]], the [[eponymous]] glaciers are diminishing rapidly. The area of each glacier has been mapped for decades by the [[National Park Service]] and the U.S. Geological Survey. Comparing photographs from the mid-19th century with contemporary images provides ample evidence that they have retreated notably since 1850. Repeat photography since clearly show that glaciers such as [[Grinnell Glacier]] are all retreating. The larger glaciers are now approximately a third of their former size when first studied in 1850, and numerous smaller glaciers have disappeared completely. Only 27% of the {{convert|99|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} area of Glacier National Park covered by glaciers in 1850 remained covered by 1993.<ref>{{cite web|author=U.S. Geological Survey |title=Glacier Monitoring in Glacier National Park |url=http://www.nrmsc.usgs.gov/research/glaciers.htm |accessdate=April 25, 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130218164617/http://www.nrmsc.usgs.gov/research/glaciers.htm |archivedate=February 18, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Researchers believe that by the year 2030, the vast majority of glacial ice in Glacier National Park will be gone unless current climate patterns reverse their course.<ref>{{cite web | author=U.S. Geological Survey, U.S. Department of the Interior | title=Glacier Retreat in Glacier National Park, Montana| url=http://nrmsc.usgs.gov/research/glacier_retreat.htm| accessdate=April 25, 2003 }}</ref> Grinnell Glacier is just one of many glaciers in Glacier National Park that have been well documented by photographs for many decades. The photographs below clearly demonstrate the retreat of this glacier since 1938.
<gallery heights="200" widths="150"> File:Grinnell Glacier 1938.jpg|1938 ''[[T.J. Hileman]] GNP'' File:Grinnell Glacier 1981.jpg|1981 ''Carl Key (USGS)'' File:Grinnell Glacier 1998.jpg|1998 ''Dan Fagre (USGS)'' File:Grinnell Glacier 2009.jpg|2009 ''Lindsey Bengtson (USGS)'' </gallery>
The semiarid climate of [[Wyoming]] still manages to support about a dozen small glaciers within [[Grand Teton National Park]], which all show evidence of retreat over the past 50 years. [[Schoolroom Glacier]] is located slightly southwest of [[Grand Teton]] is one of the more easily reached glaciers in the park and it is expected to disappear by 2025. Research between 1950 and 1999 demonstrated that the glaciers in [[Bridger-Teton National Forest]] and [[Shoshone National Forest]] in the [[Wind River Range]] shrank by over a third of their size during that period. Photographs indicate that the glaciers today are only half the size as when first photographed in the late 1890s. Research also indicates that the glacial retreat was proportionately greater in the 1990s than in any other decade over the last 100 years. [[Gannett Glacier]] on the northeast slope of [[Gannett Peak]] is the largest single glacier in the [[Rocky Mountains]] south of Canada. It has reportedly lost over 50% of its volume since 1920, with almost half of that loss occurring since 1980. Glaciologists believe the remaining glaciers in Wyoming will disappear by the middle of the 21st century if the current climate patterns continue.<ref>{{cite web | author=Wyoming Water Resources Data System Library | title=Glacial Icemelt in the Wind River Range, Wyoming | url=http://library.wrds.uwyo.edu/wrp/90-16/90-16.html | date=July 11, 1990}}</ref>
====Canadian Rockies and Coast and Columbia Mountains====
[[File:Valdez Glacier.jpg|250px|thumb|Valdez Glacier has thinned {{convert|90|m|ft|abbr=on}} over the last century, exposing barren ground near the glacial margins.<ref name=pelto5/>]]
In the [[Canadian Rockies]], glaciers are generally larger and more widespread than to the south in the Rocky Mountains. One of the more accessible in the Canadian Rockies is the [[Mount Athabasca|Athabasca Glacier]], which is an outlet glacier of the {{convert|325|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} [[Columbia Icefield]]. The Athabasca Glacier has retreated {{convert|1500|m|ft|abbr=on}} since the late 19th century. Its rate of retreat has increased since 1980, following a period of slow retreat from 1950 to 1980. The [[Peyto Glacier]] in [[Alberta]] covers an area of about {{convert|12|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}, and retreated rapidly during the first half of the 20th century, stabilized by 1966, and resumed shrinking in 1976.<ref>{{cite web | author=Canadian Cryospheric Information Network | title=Past Variability of Canadian Glaciers | url=http://www.socc.ca/cms/en/socc/glaciers/pastGlaciers.aspx | accessdate=February 14, 2006 }}</ref> The [[Illecillewaet Glacier]] in British Columbia's [[Glacier National Park (Canada)]], part of the [[Selkirk Mountains]] (west of the Rockies) has retreated {{convert|2|km|mi|abbr=on}} since first photographed in 1887.
In [[Garibaldi Provincial Park]] in Southwestern [[British Columbia]] over {{convert|505|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}, or 26%, of the park, was covered by glacier ice at the beginning of the 18th century. Ice cover decreased to {{convert|297|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} by 1987–1988 and to {{convert|245|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} by 2005, 50% of the 1850 area. The {{convert|50|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} loss in the last 20 years coincides with negative mass balance in the region. During this period all nine glaciers examined have retreated significantly.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=J. Koch, B. Menounos |author2=J. Clague |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Glacier change in Garibaldi Provincial Park, southern Coast Mountains, British Columbia, since the Little Ice Age|journal=Global and Planetary Change|volume=(3–4) 161–178|series= 66|doi=10.1016/j.gloplacha.2008.11.006|issue= 3–4 |year= 2009|pages= 161–178|bibcode = 2009GPC....66..161K }}</ref>
====Alaska==== [[File:Glacierbaymap.gif|thumb|left|Map of Glacier Bay. Red lines show glacial terminus positions and dates during retreat of the Little Ice Age glacier.]] [[File:Muir Glacier retreat.png|thumb|right|Maps showing retreat of [[Muir Glacier]] from 1941 to 1982]] There are thousands of glaciers in Alaska but only few have been named. The [[Columbia Glacier (Alaska)|Columbia Glacier]] near [[Valdez, Alaska|Valdez]] in [[Prince William Sound]] has retreated {{convert|15|km|mi|abbr=on}} in the last 25 years. Its calved icebergs partially caused the [[Exxon Valdez]] oil spill, when the tanker changed course to avoid the ice tips. The Valdez Glacier is in the same area, and though it does not calve, has also retreated significantly. "A 2005 aerial survey of Alaskan coastal glaciers identified more than a dozen glaciers, many former tidewater and [[Ice calving|calving]] glaciers, including Grand Plateau, Alsek, Bear, and Excelsior Glaciers that are rapidly retreating. Of 2,000 glaciers observed, 99% are retreating."<ref name=pelto5/> Icy Bay in Alaska is fed by three large glaciers—Guyot, Yahtse, and Tyndall Glaciers—all of which have experienced a loss in length and thickness and, consequently, a loss in area. Tyndall Glacier became separated from the retreating Guyot Glacier in the 1960s and has retreated {{convert|24|km|mi|abbr=on}} since, averaging more than {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year.<ref>{{cite web | author=Bruce F. Molnia| title=Fast-flow advance and parallel rapid retreat of non-surging tidewater glaciers in Icy Bay and Yakutat Bay, Alaska 1888–2003 |url=http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2003AM/finalprogram/abstract_65710.htm | accessdate=September 6, 2003 }}</ref>
The Juneau Icefield Research Program has monitored outlet glaciers of the [[Juneau Icefield]] since 1946. On the west side of the ice field, the terminus of the [[Mendenhall Glacier]], which flows into suburban [[Juneau, Alaska]], has retreated {{convert|580|m|ft|abbr=on}}. Of the nineteen glaciers of the Juneau Icefield, eighteen are retreating, and one, the Taku Glacier, is advancing. Eleven of the glaciers have retreated more than {{convert|1|km|mi|abbr=on}} since 1948 — Antler Glacier, {{convert|5.4|km|mi|abbr=on}}; Gilkey Glacier, {{convert|3.5|km|mi|abbr=on}}; Norris Glacier, {{convert|1.1|km|mi|abbr=on}} and Lemon Creek Glacier, {{convert|1.5|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Mauri S. Pelto |author2=Maynard M. Miller |lastauthoramp=yes | title=Terminus Behavior of Juneau Icefield Glaciers 1948–2005| work=North Cascade Glacier Climate Project| url=http://www.nichols.edu/departments/Glacier/juneau%20icefield.htm| accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> Taku Glacier has been advancing since at least 1890, when naturalist [[John Muir]] observed a large iceberg calving front. By 1948 the adjacent [[fjord]] had filled in, and the glacier no longer calved and was able to continue its advance. By 2005 the glacier was only {{convert|1.5|km|mi|abbr=on}} from reaching Taku Point and blocking [[Taku Inlet]]. The advance of Taku Glacier averaged {{convert|17|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year between 1988 and 2005. The mass balance was very positive for the 1946–88 period fueling the advance; however, since 1988 the mass balance has been slightly negative, which should in the future slow the advance of this mighty glacier.<ref>{{Cite journal |authors=Mauri S. Pelto et al. | title=The equilibrium flow and mass balance of the Taku Glacier, Alaska 1950–2006 | format=PDF | url=http://www.the-cryosphere.net/2/147/2008/tc-2-147-2008.pdf| journal=The Cryosphere|volume=2|pages=147–157|year=2008}}</ref>
Long-term mass balance records from Lemon Creek Glacier in Alaska show slightly declining mass balance with time.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Maynard M. Miller |author2=Mauri S. Pelto | title=Mass Balance Measurements of the Lemon Creek Glacier, Juneau Icefield, Alaska, 1953–2005 | url=http://www.nichols.edu/departments/glacier/Lemon.html | accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> The mean annual balance for this glacier was −{{convert|0.23|m|ft|abbr=on}} each year during the period of 1957 to 1976. Mean annual balance has been increasingly negatively averaging −{{convert|1.04|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year from 1990 to 2005. Repeat glacier altimetry, or altitude measuring, for 67 Alaska glaciers find rates of thinning have increased by more than a factor of two when comparing the periods from 1950 to 1995 ({{convert|0.7|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year) and 1995 to 2001 ({{convert|1.8|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year).<ref>{{cite journal | author=Anthony A. Arendt | title=Rapid Wastage of Alaska Glaciers and Their Contribution to Rising Sea Level | journal=Science| date= July 19, 2002| volume=297| issue=5580| pages=382–386| url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/short/297/5580/382 | pmid=12130781 | doi=10.1126/science.1072497|bibcode = 2002Sci...297..382A | author2=and others | displayauthors=1 | last3=Harrison | last4=Lingle | last5=Valentine }}</ref> This is a systemic trend with loss in mass equating to loss in thickness, which leads to increasing retreat—the glaciers are not only retreating, but they are also becoming much thinner. In [[Denali National Park]], all glaciers monitored are retreating, with an average retreat of {{convert|20|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year. The terminus of the Toklat Glacier has been retreating {{convert|26|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year and the Muldrow Glacier has thinned {{convert|20|m|ft|abbr=on}} since 1979.<ref>{{cite web | author=Guy W. Adema| title=Melting Denali: Effects of Climate Change on the Glaciers of Denali National Park and Preserve|url=http://www.nps.gov/akso/AKParkScience/ClimateChange/adema.pdf| accessdate=September 9, 2007 |format=PDF|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Well documented in Alaska are [[surge (glacier)|surging]] glaciers that have been known to rapidly advance, even as much as {{convert|100|m|ft|abbr=on}} per day. [[Variegated Glacier|Variegated]], Black Rapids, Muldrow, Susitna and Yanert are examples of surging glaciers in Alaska that have made rapid advances in the past. These glaciers are all retreating overall, punctuated by short periods of advance.
===Southern hemisphere=== ====Andes and Tierra del Fuego==== [[File:73.85851W 46.74169S.gif|thumb|Retreat of [[San Rafael Glacier]] from 1990 to 2000. [[San Quintín Glacier]] is shown in the background]] {{See also|Dry Andes|Wet Andes}} A large region of population surrounding the central and southern Andes of [[Argentina]] and [[Chile]] reside in arid areas that are dependent on water supplies from melting glaciers. The water from the glaciers also supplies rivers that have in some cases been dammed for [[hydroelectric]] power. Some researchers believe that by 2030, many of the large ice caps on the highest Andes will be gone if current climate trends continue. In Patagonia on the southern tip of the continent, the large ice caps have retreated a {{convert|1|km|mi|abbr=on}} since the early 1990s and {{convert|10|km|mi|abbr=on}} since the late 19th century. It has also been observed that Patagonian glaciers are receding at a faster rate than in any other world region.<ref>{{cite news|title=Patagonian ice in rapid retreat |date=April 27, 2000 |publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/3662975.stm}}</ref> The [[Northern Patagonian Ice Field]] lost {{convert|93|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} of glacier area during the years between 1945 and 1975, and {{convert|174|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} from 1975 to 1996, which indicates that the rate of retreat is increasing. This represents a loss of 8% of the ice field, with all glaciers experiencing significant retreat. The [[Southern Patagonian Ice Field]] has exhibited a general trend of retreat on 42 glaciers, while four glaciers were in equilibrium and two advanced during the years between 1944 and 1986. The largest retreat was on [[O'Higgins Glacier]], which during the period 1896–1995 retreated {{convert|14.6|km|mi|abbr=on}}. The [[Perito Moreno Glacier]] is {{convert|30|km|mi|abbr=on}} long and is a major outflow glacier of the Patagonian ice sheet, as well as the most visited glacier in Patagonia. Perito Moreno Glacier is in equilibrium, but has undergone frequent oscillations in the period 1947–96, with a net gain of {{convert|4.1|km|mi|abbr=on}}. This glacier has advanced since 1947, and has been essentially stable since 1992. Perito Moreno Glacier is one of three glaciers in Patagonia known to have advanced, compared to several hundred others in retreat.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Skvarca, P. |author2=R. Naruse |lastauthoramp=yes | title=Dynamic behavior of glaciar Perito Moreno, Southern Patagonia| journal=Annals of Glaciology| year=1997| volume=24| issue= 1| pages=268–271 | bibcode=1996AnGla..24..268S}}<br />{{cite journal| author= Casassa, G., H. Brecher, A. Rivera and M. Aniya| title=A century-long record of glacier O'Higgins, Patagonia| journal=Annals of Glaciology| year=1997| volume=24| issue= 1| pages=106–110 }}</ref> The two major glaciers of the Southern Patagonia Icefield to the north of Moreno, Upsala and Viedma Glacier have retreated {{convert|4.6|km|mi|abbr=on}} in 21 years and {{convert|1|km|mi|abbr=on}} in 13 years respectively.<ref>{{cite news|author=EORC|title=Huge glaciers retreat on a large scale in Patagonia, South America|date=July 15, 2005|publisher=Earth Observation research Center|url=http://www.eorc.jaxa.jp/en/imgdata/topics/2008/tp080903.html| accessdate=June 13, 2009}}</ref> In the [[Aconcagua River]] Basin, glacier retreat has resulted in a 20% loss in glacier area, declining from {{convert|151|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} to {{convert|121|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Brown, F., Rivera, A., Acuna, C.| title= Recent glaciers variations at the Aconcagua Basin, central Chilean Andes| journal=Annals of Glaciology| year=2008 | volume=48| issue=2| pages=43–48| url=http://www.glaciologia.cl/textos/bown-rivera-acuna.pdf |format=PDF | doi=10.3189/172756408784700572|bibcode = 2008AnGla..48...43B | last2= Rivera| last3= Acuña}}</ref> The [[Marinelli Glacier]] in [[Tierra del Fuego]] has been in retreat since at least 1960 through 2008.
====Oceania==== [[File:170.12806E 43.67770S.gif|thumb|250px|These glaciers in New Zealand have continued to retreat rapidly in recent years. Notice the larger terminal lakes, the retreat of the white ice (ice free of moraine cover), and the higher moraine walls due to ice thinning. [[:File:DSCN5238-muller-moraine b.jpg|Photo.]] ]] In New Zealand, mountain glaciers have been in general retreat since 1890, with an acceleration since 1920. Most have measurably thinned and reduced in size, and the snow accumulation zones have risen in elevation as the 20th century progressed. Between 1971–75 Ivory Glacier receded {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=on}} from the glacial terminus, and about 26% of its surface area was lost. Since 1980 numerous small glacial lakes formed behind the new terminal moraines of several of these glaciers. Glaciers such as Classen, Godley and Douglas now all have new glacial lakes below their terminal locations due to the glacial retreat over the past 20 years. Satellite imagery indicates that these lakes are continuing to expand. There has been significant and ongoing ice volume losses on the largest New Zealand glaciers, including the [[Tasman Glacier|Tasman]], Ivory, Classen, [[Mueller Glacier|Mueller]], Maud, [[Hooker Glacier (New Zealand)|Hooker]], Grey, Godley, Ramsay, [[Murchison Glacier|Murchison]], Therma, [[Volta Glacier|Volta]] and Douglas Glaciers. The retreat of these glaciers has been marked by expanding proglacial lakes and terminus region thinning. The loss in Southern Alps total ice volume from 1976–2014 is 34 percent of the total.<ref>{{citation | last=Salinger| first=Jim| last2= Fitzharris |first2= Blair | last3= Chinn |first3= Trevor| author-link = Jim Salinger| title=New Zealand's Southern Alps have lost a third of their ice| journal= [[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]] | url=http://theconversation.com/new-zealands-southern-alps-have-lost-a-third-of-their-ice-28916| date=July 29, 2014| accessdate=February 18, 2015}}</ref>
Several glaciers, notably the much-visited [[Fox Glacier|Fox]] and [[Franz Josef Glacier]]s on New Zealand's [[West Coast, New Zealand|West Coast]], have periodically advanced, especially during the 1990s, but the scale of these advances is small when compared to 20th-century retreat. Both are more than {{convert|2.5|km|mi|abbr=on}} shorter than a century ago. These large, rapidly flowing glaciers situated on steep slopes have been very reactive to small mass-balance changes. A few years of conditions favorable to glacier advance, such as more westerly winds and a resulting increase in snowfall, are rapidly echoed in a corresponding advance, followed by equally rapid retreat when those favorable conditions end.<ref>{{cite web | title=Glaciers of New Zealand | url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/prof/p1386h/nzealand/nzealand2.html | date=May 4, 2000 |author1 = United States Department of the Interior | authorlink1=United States Department of the Interior }}</ref> The glaciers that have been advancing in a few locations in New Zealand have been doing so due to transient local weather conditions, which have brought more precipitation and cloudier, cooler summers since 2002.<ref>{{cite news|first=Patrick|last=Goodenough|title=A Glacier Grows, Undeterred by Heated Kyoto Debate|date=July 7, 2008|publisher=Cybercast News Service|url=http://cnsnews.com/news/article/glacier-grows-undeterred-heated-kyoto-debate}}</ref>{{Clear}}
==Tropical glaciers== [[Tropical]] glaciers are located between the [[Tropic of Cancer]] and the [[Tropic of Capricorn]], in the region that lies [[latitude|23° 26′ 22″]] north or south of the [[equator]]. Strictly, a tropical glacier is located within the astronomical [[tropics]]; the area where the annual temperature variation is less than the daily variation, and is within the oscillation area of the [[Intertropical Convergence Zone]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Kaser and Osmaton|title=Tropical Glaciers|year=2002|publisher=Cambridge|isbn=978-0-521-63333-8|pages=17–18}}</ref>
Tropical glaciers are the most uncommon of all glaciers for a variety of reasons. Firstly, the regions are the warmest part of the planet. Secondly, the seasonal change is minimal with temperatures warm year round, resulting in a lack of a colder winter season in which snow and ice can accumulate. Thirdly, few taller mountains exist in these regions upon which enough cold air exists for the establishment of glaciers. Overall, tropical glaciers are smaller than those found elsewhere and are the most likely glaciers to show rapid response to changing climate patterns. A small temperature increase of only a few degrees can have almost immediate and adverse effect on tropical glaciers.<ref>{{cite web | first=Raymond| last=Pierrehumbert |authorlink=Raymond Pierrehumbert |title=Tropical Glacier Retreat |work=RealClimate |url=http://www.realclimate.org/index.php?p=157 |date=May 23, 2005| accessdate=March 8, 2010}}</ref>
Near the Equator, ice is still found in East Africa, the Andes of South America and New Guinea. The retreat of equatorial glaciers has been documented via maps and photographs covering the period from the late 1800s to nearly the present.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hastenrath|first=Stefan|title=Recession of equatorial glaciers : a photo documentation|year=2008|publisher=Sundog Publishing|location=Madison, Wis.|isbn=978-0-9729033-3-2|pages=142|url=http://www.sundogpublishing.com/shop/recession-of-equatorial-glaciers-a-photo-documenation-s-hastenrath/|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515081904/http://www.sundogpublishing.com/shop/recession-of-equatorial-glaciers-a-photo-documenation-s-hastenrath/|archivedate=2013-05-15|df=}}</ref> 99.64% of tropical glaciers are in Andean mountains of South America, 0.25% on the African glaciers of Rwenzori, Mount Kenya and Kilimanjaro, and 0.11% in the Irian Jaya region in New Guinea.<ref>{{cite book|last=Osmaton and Kaser|title=Tropical Glaciers|year=2002|publisher=Cambridge|location=New York|isbn=978-0-521-63333-8|pages=19}}</ref>
===Africa=== [[File:Glacier at summit of Mt Kilimanjaro 001.JPG|left|250px|thumb|[[Furtwängler Glacier]] atop [[Kilimanjaro]] in the foreground and snowfields and the Northern Icefields beyond.]] Almost all Africa is in [[tropical]] and [[subtropical]] climate zones. Its glaciers are found only in two isolated ranges and the [[Ruwenzori Range]]. Kilimanjaro, at {{convert|5895|m|ft|abbr=on}}, is the highest peak on the continent. Since 1912 the glacier cover on the summit of Kilimanjaro has apparently retreated 75%, and the volume of glacial ice is now 80% less than it was a century ago due to both retreat and thinning.<ref name=kilimanjaro4>{{cite web|url=http://www.geology.ohio-state.edu/news_detail.php?newsId=1 |title=Snows of Kilimanjaro Disappearing, Glacial Ice Loss Increasing |publisher=Ohio State University |accessdate=August 31, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060901111936/http://www.geology.ohio-state.edu/news_detail.php?newsId=1 |archivedate=September 1, 2006 |df= }}</ref> In the 14-year period from 1984 to 1998, one section of the glacier atop the mountain receded {{convert|300|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web | author=Andrew Wielochowski | title=Glacial recession on Kilimanjaro| url=http://www.kilimanjaro.cc/glacial-recession.htm | date=October 6, 1998}}</ref> A 2002 study determined that if current conditions continue, the glaciers atop Kilimanjaro will disappear sometime between 2015 and 2020.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Lonnie G. Thompson |author2=et alia |author-link=Lonnie Thompson |title=Kilimanjaro Ice Core Records: Evidence of Holocene Climate Change in Tropical Africa |journal=Science |date=October 18, 2002 |volume=298 |issue=5593 |pages=589–593 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/298/5593/589 |pmid=12386332 |doi=10.1126/science.1073198 |bibcode=2002Sci...298..589T |last3=Davis |last4=Henderson |last5=Brecher |last6=Zagorodnov |last7=Mashiotta |last8=Lin |last9=Mikhalenko |last10=Hardy |last11=Beer }}<br />{{cite web | author=Ohio State University | title=African Ice Core Analysis reveals catastrophic droughts, shrinking ice fields and civilization shifts | work=Ohio State Research News | url=http://researchnews.osu.edu/archive/kilicores.htm | accessdate=October 3, 2002 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040313081211/http://researchnews.osu.edu/archive/kilicores.htm | archivedate=March 13, 2004 | df= }}</ref> A March 2005 report indicated that there is almost no remaining glacial ice on the mountain, and it is the first time in 11,000 years that barren ground has been exposed on portions of the summit.<ref>{{cite news|first=Guardian|last=Unlimited|title=The peak of Mt Kilimanjaro as it has not been seen for 11,000 years |date=March 14, 2005|publisher=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/climatechange/story/0,,1437901,00.html}}<br />{{cite web | last = Tyson | first = Peter | url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/kilimanjaro/vanishing.html | title = Vanishing into Thin Air | work = Volcano Above the Clouds | publisher = NOVA | accessdate = August 7, 2016}}</ref> Researchers reported Kilimanjaro's glacier retreat was due to a combination of increased [[sublimation (chemistry)|sublimation]] and decreased snow fall.<ref name=mote-kaser/>
The [[Furtwängler Glacier]] is located near the summit of Kilimanjaro. Between 1976 and 2000, the area of Furtwängler Glacier was cut almost in half, from {{convert|113000|m2|ft2|abbr=on}} to {{convert|60000|m2|ft2|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web | last = Thompson | first = Lonnie G.| url = http://www.geo.umass.edu/climate/doug/pubs/thompson_etal_sci02.pdf | title = Kilimanjaro Ice Core Records: Evidence of Holocene Climate Change in Tropical Africa | format = PDF | publisher = Science | accessdate = August 31, 2006 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> During fieldwork conducted early in 2006, scientists discovered a large hole near the center of the glacier. This hole, extending through the {{convert|6|m|ft|abbr=on}} remaining thickness of the glacier to the underlying rock, was expected to grow and split the glacier in two by 2007.<ref name=kilimanjaro4/>
To the north of Kilimanjaro lies [[Mount Kenya]], which at {{convert|5199|m|ft|abbr=on}} is the second tallest mountain on the continent. Mount Kenya has a number of small glaciers that have lost at least 45% of their mass since the middle of the 20th century. According to research compiled by the [[U.S. Geological Survey]] (USGS), there were eighteen glaciers atop Mount Kenya in 1900, and by 1986 only eleven remained. The total area covered by glaciers was {{convert|1.6|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} in 1900, however by the year 2000 only about 25%, or {{convert|0.4|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} remained.<ref>{{cite web | author=U.S. Geological Survey | title=Glaciers of Africa | work=U.S. Geological Survey Professional Paper 1386-G-3 | format=PDF | url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/prof/p1386g/africa.pdf#search='USGS%20Mount%20Kilimanjaro%20glacier'}}</ref> To the west of Mounts Kilimanjaro and Kenya, the Ruwenzori Range rises to {{convert|5109|m|ft|abbr=on}}. Photographic evidence indicates a marked reduction in glacially covered areas over the past century. In the 35-year period between 1955 and 1990, glaciers on the [[Rwenzori Mountains]] receded about 40%. It is expected that due to their proximity to the heavy moisture of the [[Congo River|Congo]] region, the glaciers in the Ruwenzori Range may recede at a slower rate than those on Kilimanjaro or in Kenya.<ref>{{cite web | author=Andrew Wielochowski | title=Glacial recession in the Rwenzori | url=http://www.kilimanjaro.cc/rwenzoriglaciers.htm | accessdate=July 20, 2007}}</ref>
===South America=== A study by glaciologists of two small glaciers in South America reveals another retreat. More than 80% of all glacial ice in the northern Andes is concentrated on the highest peaks in small plains of approximately {{convert|1|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} in size. A 1992 to 1998 observation of the [[Chacaltaya]] Glacier in [[Bolivia]] and Antizana Glacier in [[Ecuador]] indicate that between {{convert|0.6|m|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|1.9|m|ft|abbr=on}} of ice was lost per year on each glacier. Figures for Chacaltaya show a loss of 67% of its volume and 40% of its thickness over the same period. Chacaltaya Glacier has lost 90% of its mass since 1940 and was expected to disappear altogether sometime between 2010 and 2015. Antizana is also reported to have lost 40% of its surface area between 1979 and 2007.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tegel|first=Simeon|title=Antisana's Glaciers: Victims of Climate Change|url=http://pulitzercenter.org/reporting/equador-antisana-melting-glaciers-climate-change|publisher=GlobalPost|accessdate=13 August 2012|date=2012-07-17}}</ref> Research also indicates that since the mid-1980s, the rate of retreat for both of these glaciers has been increasing.<ref>{{cite web | author=Bernard Francou| title=Small Glaciers Of The Andes May Vanish In 10–15 Years| work=UniSci, International Science News| url=http://unisci.com/stories/20011/0117013.htm | accessdate=January 22, 2001 }}</ref> In [[Colombia]], the glaciers atop [[Nevado del Ruiz]] have lost more than half their area in the last 40 years.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Huggel|first=Cristian|author2=Ceballos, Jorge Luis |author3=Pulgarín, Bernardo |author4=Ramírez, Jair |author5= Thouret, Jean-Claude |title=Review and reassessment of hazards owing to volcano–glacier interactions in Colombia|year=2007|volume=45|issue=1|journal=Annals of Glaciology|pages=128–136|url=http://www.igsoc.org/annals/45/a45A019.pdf|doi=10.3189/172756407782282408|format=PDF|bibcode = 2007AnGla..45..128H }}</ref> Further south in [[Peru]], the Andes are at a higher altitude overall, and there are approximately 722 glaciers covering an area of {{convert|723|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}.
Research in the region has been less extensive but indicates an overall recline of 7% between 1977 and 1983.<ref>{{cite web | author=U.S. Geological Survey, U.S. Department of the Interior | title=Peruvian Cordilleras| url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/prof/p1386i/peru/occident.html| accessdate=February 9, 2007}}</ref> The [[Quelccaya Ice Cap]] is the second largest tropical icecap in the world after the [[Coropuna]] ice cap,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kochtitzky|first1=William H.|last2=Edwards|first2=Benjamin R.|last3=Enderlin|first3=Ellyn M.|last4=Marino|first4=Jersy|last5=Marinque|first5=Nelida|title=Improved estimates of glacier change rates at Nevado Coropuna Ice Cap, Peru|journal=Journal of Glaciology|date=2018|volume=64|issue=244|pages=175–184|doi=10.1017/jog.2018.2|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-glaciology/article/improved-estimates-of-glacier-change-rates-at-nevado-coropuna-ice-cap-peru/AE2C29B25C4757967B2C6CEB8C918C33|language=en|issn=0022-1430|bibcode=2018JGlac..64..175K}}</ref> and all of the outlet glaciers from the icecap are retreating.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/05/world/americas/1600-years-of-ice-in-perus-andes-melted-in-25-years-scientists-say.html ''In Sign of Warming, 1,600 Years of Ice in Andes Melted in 25 Years''] April 4, 2013 New York Times</ref> In the case of [[Qori Kalis Glacier]], which is one of Quelccayas' outlet glaciers, the rate of retreat had reached {{convert|155|m|ft|abbr=on}} per year during the three-year period of 1995 to 1998. The melting ice has formed a large lake at the front of the glacier since 1983, and bare ground has been exposed for the first time in thousands of years.<ref>{{cite web | author=Byrd Polar Research Center, The Ohio State University| title=Peru – Quelccaya (1974–1983)| work=Ice Core Paleoclimatology Research Group| url=http://www-bprc.mps.ohio-state.edu/Icecore/Quelccaya.html| accessdate=February 10, 2006 }}</ref>
===Oceania=== [[File:Puncak Jaya glaciers 1850-2003 evolution map-fr.gif|thumb|right|Animated map of the extent of the glaciers of the [[Puncak Jaya|Carstensz Range]] from 1850 to 2003]] [[File:Puncak Jaya icecap 1936.jpg|250px|thumb|[[Mount Carstensz]] icecap 1936 USGS]][[File:Puncak Jaya icecap 1972.jpg|250px|thumb|Puncak Jaya glaciers 1972. Left to right: Northwall Firn, Meren Glacier, and Carstensz Glacier. USGS. [[:File:137.13987E 4.06651S 06 2005.jpg|Also mid-2005 image]] and [[:File:137.13211E 4.05959S.gif|animation.]] ]] [[Jan Carstensz]]'s 1623 report of glaciers covering the [[List of highest mountains of New Guinea|equatorial mountains]] of [[New Guinea]] was originally met with ridicule, but in the early 20th century at least five subranges of the [[Maoke Mountains]] (meaning "Snowy Mountains") were indeed still found to be covered with large ice caps. Due to the location of the island within the tropical zone, there is little to no seasonal variation in temperature. The tropical location has a predictably steady level of rain and snowfall, as well as cloud cover year round, and there has been no noticeable change in the amount of moisture which has fallen during the 20th century.
In 1913, {{convert|4550|m|ft|abbr=on}} high Prins Hendrik peaks (now [[Puncak Yamin]]) was named and reported to have "eternal" snow, but this observation was never repeated.<ref>E.J. Brill, Tijdschrift van het Koninklijk Nederlandsch Aardrijkskundig Genootschap, 1913, p. 180.</ref> The ice cap of {{convert|4720|m|ft|abbr=on}} [[Puncak Trikora|Wilhelmina Peaks]], which reached below {{convert|4400|m|ft|abbr=on}} in 1909, vanished between 1939 and 1963.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Ian Allison |author2=James A. Peterson |lastauthoramp=yes | title=Glaciers of Irian Jaya, Indonesia and New Zealand | work=U.S. Geological Survey, U.S. Department of the Interior| url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/prof/p1386h/indonesia/indonesia.html | accessdate=April 28, 2009 }}</ref> The [[Puncak Mandala|Mandala / Juliana]] ice cap disappeared in the 1990s.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Klein | first1 = A.G. | last2 = Kincaid | first2 = J.L. | year = 2008 | title = On the disappearance of the Puncak Mandala ice cap, Papua | url = | journal = Journal of Glaciology | volume = 54 | issue = 184| pages = 195–198 | bibcode = 2008JGlac..54..195K | doi = 10.3189/S0022143000209994 }}</ref> and the Idenburg glacier on [[Ngga Pilimsit]] dried up in 2003. This leaves only the remnants of the once continuous icecap on New Guinea's highest mountain, [[Mount Carstensz]] with the {{convert|4884|m|ft|abbr=on}} high [[Puncak Jaya]] summit, which is estimated to have had an area of {{convert|20|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} in 1850.
For this mountain there is photographic evidence of massive glacial retreat since the region was first extensively explored by airplane in 1936 in preparation for the [[Carstensz Expedition|peak's first ascent]]. Between then and 2010, the mountain lost 80 percent of its ice — two-thirds of which since another scientific expedition in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite news|last=McDowell |first=Robin |title=Indonesia’s Last Glacier Will Melt ‘Within Years’ |url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/home/indonesias-last-glacier-will-melt-within-years/383607 |accessdate=2011-10-23 |newspaper=Jakarta Globe |date=July 1, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816134134/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/home/indonesias-last-glacier-will-melt-within-years/383607 |archivedate=August 16, 2011 |df= }}</ref> That research between 1973 and 1976 showed glacier retreat for the Meren Glacier of {{convert|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} while the [[Carstensz Glacier]] lost {{convert|50|m|ft|abbr=on}}. The Northwall Firn, the largest remnant of the icecap that once was atop [[Puncak Jaya]], has itself split into two separate glaciers after 1942. [[IKONOS]] [[satellite imagery]] of the New Guinean glaciers indicated that by 2002 only {{convert|2.1|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} glacial area remained, that in the two years from 2000 to 2002, the [[East Northwall Firn]] had lost 4.5%, the [[West Northwall Firn]] 19.4% and the Carstensz 6.8% of their glacial mass, and that sometime between 1994 and 2000, the Meren Glacier had disappeared altogether.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Joni L. Kincaid |author2=Andrew G. Klein |lastauthoramp=yes | title=Retreat of the Irian Jaya Glaciers from 2000 to 2002 as Measured from IKONOS Satellite Images| format=PDF| work=61st Eastern Snow Conference Portland, Maine, USA 2004| url=http://www.easternsnow.org/proceedings/2004/kincaid_and_klein.pdf#search='meren%20glacier'| accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> An expedition to the remaining glaciers on Puncak Jaya in 2010 discovered that the ice on the glaciers there is about {{convert|32|m|ft}} thick and thinning at a rate of {{convert|7|m|ft}} annually. At that rate, the remaining glaciers were expected to last only to the year 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jakarta Globe |title=Papua Glacier's Secrets Dripping Away: Scientists |date=July 2, 2010 |url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/papua-glaciers-secrets-dripping-away-scientists/383881 |accessdate=2010-09-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811204935/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/papua-glaciers-secrets-dripping-away-scientists/383881 |archivedate=August 11, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==Polar regions== Despite their proximity and importance to human populations, the mountain and valley glaciers of tropical and mid-latitude glaciers amount to only a small fraction of glacial ice on the Earth. About 99 percent of all freshwater ice is in the great ice sheets of polar and subpolar [[Antarctica]] and [[Greenland]]. These continuous continental-scale ice sheets, {{convert|3|km|mi|abbr=on}} or more in thickness, cap much of the polar and subpolar land masses. Like rivers flowing from an enormous lake, numerous outlet glaciers transport ice from the margins of the ice sheet to the ocean.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kusky|first=Timothy|title=Encyclopedia of Earth and Space Science|year=2010|publisher=Facts on File|isbn=978-0-8160-7005-3|pages=343|url=https://books.google.com/?id=vMk4t21fOvoC&pg=PA343&dq=most+of+the+world's+ice+is+locked+up+in+antarctica+and+greenland#|accessdate=2011-10-15}}</ref>
===Iceland=== The northern Atlantic island nation of [[Iceland]] is home to [[Vatnajökull]], which is the largest ice cap in Europe. The [[Breiðamerkurjökull]] glacier is one of Vatnajökull's outlet glaciers, and receded by as much as {{convert|2|km|mi|abbr=on}} between 1973 and 2004. In the early 20th century, Breiðamerkurjökull extended to within {{convert|250|m|ft|abbr=on}} of the ocean, but by 2004 its terminus had retreated {{convert|3|km|mi|abbr=on}} further inland. This glacier retreat exposed a rapidly expanding lagoon, [[Jökulsárlón]], which is filled with icebergs calved from its front. Jökulsárlón is {{convert|110|m|ft|abbr=on}} deep and nearly doubled its size between 1994 and 2004. Mass-balance measurements of Iceland's glaciers show alternating positive and negative mass balance of glaciers during the period 1987–95, but the mass balance has been predominantly negative since. On Hofsjökull ice cap, mass balance has been negative each year from 1995–2005.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sveinsson|first=Óli Gretar Blondal|title=XXV Nordic Hydrological Conference|url=http://www.vedur.is/media/vatnafar/saga/NHC2008_volume2_web.pdf|publisher=Nordic Association for Hydrology|accessdate=2011-10-15|format=pdf|date=August 11–13, 2008}}</ref>
Most of the Icelandic glaciers retreated rapidly during the warm decades from 1930 to 1960, slowing down as the climate cooled during the following decade, and started to advance after 1970. The rate of advance peaked in the 1980s, after which it slowed down until about 1990. As a consequence of rapid warming of the climate that has taken place since the mid-1980s, most glaciers in Iceland began to retreat after 1990, and by 2000 all monitored non-surge type glaciers in Iceland were retreating. An average of 45 non-surging termini were monitored each year by the Icelandic Glaciological Society from 2000–2005.<ref>{{cite web | author=Sigurdsson, Oddur, Trausti Jonsson and Tomas Johannesson| title=Relation between glacier-termini variations and summer temperature in Iceland since 1930| format=PDF| website= | publisher=Hydrological Service, National Energy Authority| url=http://www.igsoc.org/annals/46/a46A210.pdf| accessdate=September 7, 2007}}</ref>
===Canada=== {{See also|Ward Hunt Island}} [[File:Bylot Islandedit.png|thumb|280px|Bylot Ice Cap on Bylot Island, one of the [[Canadian Arctic islands]], August 14, 1975 (USGS)]] The [[Canadian Arctic islands]] contain the largest area and volume of land ice on Earth outside of the Greenland and Antarctic Ice Sheets<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Radić | first1 = V. | last2 = Hock | first2 = R. | year = 2010 | title = Regional and global volumes of glaciers derived from statistical upscaling ofglacier inventory data | url = | journal = J. Geophys. Res. | volume = 115 | issue = F1| page = F01010 | doi=10.1029/2009jf001373 | bibcode=2010JGRF..115.1010R}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sharp | first1 = M. | last2 = Burgess | first2 = D. O. | last3 = Cogley | first3 = J. G. | last4 = Ecclestone | first4 = M. | last5 = Labine | first5 = C. | last6 = Wolken | first6 = G. J. | year = 2011 | title = Extreme melt onCanada's Arctic ice caps in the 21st century | url = | journal = Geophys. Res. Lett. | volume = 38 | issue = 11| page = L11501 | doi=10.1029/2011gl047381 | bibcode=2011GeoRL..3811501S}}</ref> and is home to a number of substantial ice caps, including [[Penny Ice Cap|Penny]] and [[Barnes Ice Cap|Barnes]] ice caps on [[Baffin Island]], Bylot Ice Cap on [[Bylot Island]], and [[Devon Ice Cap]] on [[Devon Island]]. Glaciers in the Canadian Arctic were near equilibrium between 1960 and 2000, losing 23 Gt of ice per year between 1995 and 2000.<ref>{{cite journal | author=W. Abdalatiia| title=Elevation changes of ice caps in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago (Abstract)| journal=American Geophysical Union| date= November 20, 2004| volume=109 | pages=F04007| issue=F04007| url=http://www.agu.org/pubs/crossref/2004/2003JF000045.shtml| displayauthors=etal }}</ref> Since this time, Canadian Arctic glaciers have experienced a sharp increase in mass loss in response to warmer summer temperature, losing 92 Gt per year between 2007 and 2009 .<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gardner | first1 = A. S. | last2 = Moholdt | first2 = G. | last3 = Wouters | first3 = B. | last4 = Wolken | first4 = G. J. | last5 = Burgess | first5 = D. O. | last6 = Sharp | first6 = M. J. | last7 = Cogley | first7 = J. G. | last8 = Braun | first8 = C. | year = 2011 | title = Sharply increased mass loss from glaciers and ice caps in theCanadian Arctic Archipelago | url = | journal = Nature | volume = 473 | issue = 7347| pages = 357–360 | doi=10.1038/nature10089|bibcode = 2011Natur.473..357G | pmid=21508960}}</ref>
Other studies show that between 1960 and 1999, the Devon Ice Cap lost {{convert|67|km3|mi3|abbr=on}} of ice, mainly through thinning. All major outlet glaciers along the eastern Devon Ice Cap margin have retreated from {{convert|1|km|mi|abbr=on}} to {{convert|3|km|mi|abbr=on}} since 1960.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=David O. Burgess |author2=Martin J. Sharpa |lastauthoramp=yes | title=Recent Changes in Areal Extent of the Devon Ice Cap, Nunavut, Canada| journal=BioOne| volume=36| issue=2| pages=261–271| url=http://www.bioone.org/bioone/?request=get-abstract&issn=1523-0430&volume=036&issue=02&page=0261| doi=10.1657/1523-0430(2004)036[0261:RCIAEO]2.0.CO;2 | issn=1523-0430| year=2004}}</ref> On the Hazen Plateau of [[Ellesmere Island]], the Simmon Ice Cap has lost 47% of its area since 1959.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Braun, Carsten |author2=Hardy, D.R. |author3=Bradley, R.S. |last-author-amp=yes | title= Mass balance and area changes of four High Arctic plateau ice caps, 1959–2002 | journal= Geografiska Annaler| year= 2004| volume= 86| issue= A| pages= 43–52| url=http://www.geo.umass.edu/faculty/bradley/braun2004.pdf| doi= 10.1111/j.0435-3676.2004.00212.x|format=PDF}}</ref> If the current climatic conditions continue, the remaining glacial ice on the Hazen Plateau will be gone around 2050. On August 13, 2005, the [[Ayles Ice Shelf]] broke free from the north coast of Ellesmere Island. The {{convert|66|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} ice shelf drifted into the Arctic Ocean.<ref>{{cite web | author=National Geographic| title=Giant Ice Shelf Breaks Off in Canadian Arctic | url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2006/12/061229-arctic-ice.html| accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> This followed the splitting of the Ward Hunt Ice Shelf in 2002. The Ward Hunt has lost 90% of its area in the last century.<ref>{{cite journal | authors=Derek R. Mueller, Warwick F. Vincent, and Martin O. Jeffries| title=Break-up of the largest Arctic ice shelf and associated loss of an epishelf lake|doi=10.1029/2003GL017931|date=October 2003|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|volume=30|issue=20|page=2031| bibcode=2003GeoRL..30.2031M}}</ref>
===Northern Europe=== Arctic islands north of Norway, [[Finland]] and Russia have all shown evidence of glacier retreat. In the [[Svalbard]] [[archipelago]], the island of [[Spitsbergen]] has numerous glaciers. Research indicates that Hansbreen (Hans Glacier) on Spitsbergen retreated {{convert|1.4|km|mi|abbr=on}} from 1936 to 1982 and another {{convert|400|m|ft|abbr=on}} during the 16-year period from 1982 to 1998.<ref>{{cite web | author=Glowacki, Piotr| title=Glaciology and environmental monitoring | work=Research in Hornsund| url=http://hornsund.igf.edu.pl/srodowisko_en.html | accessdate=February 14, 2006 }}</ref> Blomstrandbreen, a glacier in the King's Bay area of Spitsbergen, has retreated approximately {{convert|2|km|mi|abbr=on}} in the past 80 years. Since 1960 the average retreat of Blomstrandbreen has been about {{convert|35|m|ft|abbr=on}} a year, and this average was enhanced due to an accelerated rate of retreat since 1995.<ref>{{cite web | author=GreenPeace| year=2002| title=Arctic environment melts before our eyes | work=Global Warming—Greenpeace Pictures in Spitsbergen | url=http://www.svalbard-images.com/spitsbergen/global-warming-e.php | accessdate=February 14, 2006 }}</ref> Similarly, Midre Lovenbreen retreated {{convert|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} between 1977 and 1995.<ref>{{cite journal | author= David Rippin, Ian Willis, Neil Arnold, Andrew Hodson, John Moore, Jack Kohler and Helgi Bjornsson| title= Changes in Geometry and Subglacial Drainage of Midre Lovenbreen, Svalbard, Determined from Digital Elevation Models | journal= [[Earth Surface Processes and Landforms]]| year= 2003| volume= 28| issue=3| pages= 273–298| url= http://arcticcentre.ulapland.fi/docs/jmoore/Rippin_et_al_2003.pdf | doi= 10.1002/esp.485 |format=PDF |bibcode = 2003ESPL...28..273R }}</ref> In the [[Novaya Zemlya]] archipelago north of Russia, research indicates that in 1952 there was {{convert|208|km|mi|abbr=on}} of glacier ice along the coast. By 1993 this had been reduced by 8% to {{convert|198|km|mi|abbr=on}} of glacier coastline.<ref>{{cite journal | author= Aleksey I. Sharov| title= Studying changes of ice coasts in the European Arctic | journal= Geo-Marine Letters| year= 2005| volume= 25 | issue= 2–3| pages= 153–166| url= http://dib.joanneum.at/integral/publications%5CGML_Sharov.pdf| doi= 10.1007/s00367-004-0197-7|format=PDF|bibcode = 2005GML....25..153S }}</ref>
===Greenland=== [[File:Retreat of the Helheim Glacier, Greenland.jpg|thumb|300px|Retreat of the Helheim Glacier, Greenland]] In [[Greenland]], glacier retreat has been observed in outlet glaciers, resulting in an increase of the ice flow rate and destabilization of the mass balance of the ice sheet that is their source. The net loss in volume and hence sea level contribution of the Greenland Ice Sheet (GIS) has doubled in recent years from {{convert|90|km3|mi3|abbr=on}} per year in 1996 to {{convert|220|km3|mi3|abbr=on}} per year in 2005.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Rignot, E. |author2=Kanagaratnam, P. |lastauthoramp=yes | title=Changes in the Velocity Structure of the Greenland Ice Sheet| journal=Science| date=February 17, 2006| volume=311| issue=5763| pages=986–990| url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/311/5763/986| doi=10.1126/science.1121381| pmid=16484490|bibcode = 2006Sci...311..986R }}</ref> Researchers also noted that the acceleration was widespread affecting almost all glaciers south of 70 N by 2005. The period since 2000 has brought retreat to several very large glaciers that had long been stable. Three glaciers that have been researched—[[Helheim Glacier]], [[Kangerdlugssuaq Glacier]], and [[Jakobshavn Isbræ]]—jointly drain more than 16% of the [[Greenland Ice Sheet]]. In the case of Helheim Glacier, researchers used satellite images to determine the movement and retreat of the glacier. Satellite images and aerial photographs from the 1950s and 1970s show that the front of the glacier had remained in the same place for decades. In 2001 the glacier began retreating rapidly, and by 2005 the glacier had retreated a total of {{convert|7.2|km|mi|abbr=on}}, accelerating from {{convert|20|m|ft|abbr=on}} per day to {{convert|35|m|ft|abbr=on}} per day during that period.<ref>{{cite web | author=Ian Howat | title=Rapidly accelerating glaciers may increase how fast the sea level rises | work=UC Santa Cruz, November 14–27, 2005 Vol. 10, No. 14 | url=http://currents.ucsc.edu/05-06/11-14/glacier.asp |accessdate=November 27, 2007}}</ref>
Jakobshavn Isbræ in west Greenland, a major outlet glacier of the Greenland Ice Sheet, has been the fastest moving glacier in the world over the past half century. It had been moving continuously at speeds of over {{convert|24|m|ft|abbr=on}} per day with a stable terminus since at least 1950. In 2002 the {{convert|12|km|mi|abbr=on}} long floating terminus of the glacier entered a phase of rapid retreat, with the ice front breaking up and the floating terminus disintegrating and accelerating to a retreat rate of over {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=on}} per day. On a shorter timescale, portions of the main trunk of Kangerdlugssuaq Glacier that were flowing at {{convert|15|m|ft|abbr=on}} per day from 1988 to 2001 were measured to be flowing at {{convert|40|m|ft|abbr=on}} per day in the summer of 2005. Not only has Kangerdlugssuaq retreated, it has also thinned by more than {{convert|100|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web | author=M Truffer, University of Alaska Fairbanks; M Fahnestock, University of New Hampshire | title=The Dynamics of Glacier System Response: Tidewater Glaciers and the Ice Streams and Outlet Glaciers of Greenland and Antarctica I |url=http://www.agu.org/meetings/fm05/fm05-sessions/fm05_C41A.html | archivedate=April 22, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060422071200/http://www.agu.org/meetings/fm05/fm05-sessions/fm05_C41A.html|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
The rapid thinning, acceleration and retreat of Helheim, Jakobshavns and Kangerdlugssuaq glaciers in Greenland, all in close association with one another, suggests a common triggering mechanism, such as enhanced surface melting due to regional climate warming or a change in forces at the glacier front. The enhanced melting leading to lubrication of the glacier base has been observed to cause a small seasonal velocity increase and the release of meltwater lakes has also led to only small short term accelerations.<ref>{{cite journal | author=S. Das, I, Joughin, M. Behm, I. Howat, M. King, D. Lizarralde, M. Bhatia | title=Fracture Propagation to the Base of the Greenland Ice Sheet During Supraglacial Lake Drainage| url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1153360| journal=Science|date=9 May 2008|volume=320|issue=5877|pages=778–781|doi=10.1126/science.1153360| pmid=18420900|bibcode=2008Sci...320..778D| hdl=1912/2506}}</ref> The significant accelerations noted on the three largest glaciers began at the calving front and propagated inland and are not seasonal in nature.<ref name=greenland-pelto>{{cite web | author=M. Pelto | title=Moulins, Calving Fronts and Greenland Outlet Glacier Acceleration| url=http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2008/04/moulins-calving-fronts-and-greenland-outlet-glacier-acceleration/#more-550| accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> Thus, the primary source of outlet glacier acceleration widely observed on small and large calving glaciers in Greenland is driven by changes in dynamic forces at the glacier front, not enhanced meltwater lubrication.<ref name=greenland-pelto/> This was termed the ''Jakobshavns Effect'' by Terence Hughes at the [[University of Maine]] in 1986.<ref>{{cite journal | author=T. Hughes | title=The Jakobshanvs effect | journal=[[Geophysical Research Letters]]| year=1986| volume=13| issue=1| pages=46–48| bibcode=1986GeoRL..13...46H | doi=10.1029/GL013i001p00046}}</ref> Indeed, a study published in 2015 on glacial underwater topography at 3 sites found cavities, due to warm subglacial water intrusion, which has been identified as a possible dominant force for ablation (surface erosion). Thus, suggests ocean temperature controls ice sheet surface runoff at specific sites. These findings also show that models underestimate the sensitivity of Greenland glaciers to ocean warming and resulting ice sheet runoff. Hence, without better modelling, new observations suggest that past projections of sea level rise attribution from the Greenland Ice Sheet require upward revision.<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|volume=42 |issue=14 |pages=5909–5917 |author1=Eric Rignot |author2=Ian Fenty |author3=Yun Xu |author4=Cilan Cai |author5=Chris Kemp |year=2015|title=Undercutting of marine-terminating glaciers in West Greenland|doi=10.1002/2015GL064236|url=http://escholarship.org/uc/item/28j711jc|bibcode=2015GeoRL..42.5909R}}</ref>
===Antarctica=== {{See also|List of glaciers in the Antarctic|List of Antarctic ice shelves}} [[File:Larsen B Collapse.jpg|thumb|250px|The collapsing Larsen B Ice Shelf in [[Antarctica]] is similar in area to the U.S. state of [[Rhode Island]].]] [[climate of Antarctica|Antarctica]] is intensely cold and arid. Most of the world's freshwater ice is contained within its sheets. Its most dramatic example of glacier retreat is the loss of large sections of the [[Larsen Ice Shelf]] on the [[Antarctic Peninsula]]. The recent collapse of Wordie Ice Shelf, Prince Gustav Ice Shelf, Mueller Ice Shelf, Jones Ice Shelf, Larsen-A and Larsen-B Ice Shelf on the Antarctic Peninsula has raised awareness of how dynamic ice shelf systems are.
The Antarctic sheet is the largest known single mass of ice. It covers almost 14 million km<sup>2</sup> and some 30 million km<sup>3</sup> of ice. Around 90% of the fresh water on the planet's surface is held in this area and if melted would raise sea levels by 58 metres.<ref name="IPCC">[http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/412.htm#tab113 ''Physical characteristics of ice on Earth'', Climate Change 2001: Working Group I: The Scientific Basis. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)]</ref> The continent-wide average surface temperature trend of Antarctica is positive and significant at >0.05 °C/decade since 1957.<ref name="SteigSchneider2009">{{cite journal|journal=Nature|year=2009|doi=10.1038/nature07669|title=Warming of the Antarctic ice-sheet surface since the 1957|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v457/n7228/abs/nature07669.html|authors=Eric J. Steig, David P. Schneider, Scott D. Rutherford, Michael E. Mann, Josefino C. Comiso & Drew T. Shindell|pmid=19158794|volume=457|issue=7228|pages=459–62|bibcode = 2009Natur.457..459S }}</ref>
The Antarctic sheet is divided by the [[Transantarctic Mountains]] into two unequal sections known as the [[East Antarctic ice sheet]] (EAIS) and the smaller [[West Antarctic Ice Sheet]] (WAIS). The EAIS rests on a major land mass but the bed of the WAIS is, in places, more than 2,500 metres below [[sea level]]. It would be [[seabed]] if the ice sheet were not there. The WAIS is classified as a marine-based ice sheet, meaning that its bed lies below sea level and its edges flow into floating ice shelves. The WAIS is bounded by the [[Ross Ice Shelf]], the [[Ronne Ice Shelf]], and outlet glaciers that drain into the [[Amundsen Sea]].
Ice shelves are not stable when surface melting occurs, and the collapse of Larsen Ice Shelf has been caused by warmer melt season temperatures that have led to surface melting and the formation of shallow ponds of water on the ice shelf. The Larsen Ice Shelf lost {{convert|2500|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} of its area from 1995 to 2001. In a 35-day period beginning on January 31, 2002, about {{convert|3250|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} of shelf area disintegrated. The ice shelf is now 40% the size of its previous minimum stable extent.<ref>{{cite web | author=National Snow and Ice Data Center | title=Larsen B Ice Shelf Collapses in Antarctica| work=The Cryosphere, Where the World is Frozen| url=http://nsidc.org/news/press/larsen_B/2002.html| date=March 21, 2002| accessdate=November 5, 2009 }}</ref> In 2015 a study concluded that the remaining ''Larsen B'' ice-shelf will disintegrate by the end of the decade, based on observations of faster flow and rapid thinning of glaciers in the area.<ref>{{cite web|title=NASA Study Shows Antarctica's Larsen B Ice Shelf Nearing Its Final Act|url=http://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasa-study-shows-antarctica-s-larsen-b-ice-shelf-nearing-its-final-act|author=NASA|date=14 May 2015}}</ref> Jones Ice Shelf had an area of {{convert|35|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} in the 1970s but by 2008 it had disappeared.<ref name=apis>{{cite journal |author1=A. J. Cook |author2=D. G.
